reviewText:
After an hour of playing, I am more than equipped to give my thoughts about this game.

Score: 7.5/10

++Fluid animation
+Variety of characters (plus 2 more if you buy the Lilith DLC. Lilith DLC includes Hilda.)
++Really nice music
+Awesome anime girls (moe and panty shots included)

--Insane learning curve
-Semi-difficult with keyboard alone

+/-Almost all characters share the same combo/Special Move inputs (this could be good/bad depending on your view)

[[ IF YOU PLAY KEYBOARD STYLE LIKE ME, DISABLE THE GAME CONTROLER OPTION VIA GAME MENU AND REBIND KEYS BEFORE DOING ANYTHING ]]

As I'm used to these types of fighting games I mostly saw BlazeBlue in this and thought it was pretty similar. I was right. Technically all 2D fighters are the same, but that's another discussion. For the most part I love it. The anime characters are interesting, but with the amount of anime nowadays, you could probably say they remind you of other series/characters--whether in games or another.

Jumping straight into the Arcade mode is a very big NO. I got my *** kicked so bad and won the first match by button mashing. The second fight was impossible. Not because it was difficult, it's because I didn't know how to play it. By luck I got back to the menu screen and did a complete overhaul of the keybindings through trial and error. I find it works best if you use ASD for Light, Mid, and Heavy attacks respectively. W for Parry, and Q for support. And the Directional Arrows for movement. This works best for me. After 5min of Arcade sessions for practice you can easily learn many of the combos. I learned all the combos for all the fighters so I know how to challenge them with whichever character I choose to play as. (Versus may not have an AI, but it's perfect for learning how to play the game.)

However, the Story mode is still relentless. The difficulty, even knowing how to form combos, was still a little high. The first few matches were easy, but difficulty continues to rise. I haven't beat it yet but I'm sure I will if I sit and focus. Animation wise there's lots of motion. LOTS of motion. Lots of bouncing for each character showing off their assets. Overall it is smooth and seems to flow pretty nicely. The only downside is that you can sometimes see the tiny white pixels around the fighters. They're even noticable in the Character Select screen. This is a small detail I can look over.

As for the Support they added into the game. I honestly don't use them. Only rarely do I do or find them useful. The music on the other hand, now that's something to get into. Just about every track--except for maybe three--I really loved causing my foot to tap while I'm laying down combos. (The Shrine music is my favorite.)

At this point this is all I really have to say. Hopefully, if you read this, will help those that play Keyboard style. I like Game Controllers as well, but PC games MUST be played using the keyboard. At least for me anyways. It adds a difficulty that many people hate, but is oh so satisfying when you show your stuff.

reviewText:
This game is no mere fighting game. It is a dangerous journey of self-discovery, but an important one. It is a ticket to ride to a far-off land. A strange, bizarre, sometimes even frightening place. A place where two-dimensional beings walk the land. A place full of peculiar hair style decisions, bright colors and the sex fantasies of reclusive Japanese animators and artists. A place containing not just vanguard princesses, but bubblegum crises, robots that drill through universes, homoerotic vampires being pursued by muscular men with magic demons, dandy guys in space, little girls running item shops, the most convoluted fighting game storyline ever written, women who interact through games of Match 3 and Hyperdimension Neptunia.

Ready yourself as you step into this world, for I cannot promise you will come out the same person you are today, if you ever emerge at all. You may find yourself becoming unnaturally attached to one of the many denizens, claiming a so-called waifu, or a husbando, or some bizarre mix of both, and collecting frivolous merchandise to line the walls of your personal cavern of kawaii. As you descend into this world, you may find yourself growing distant from those around you, only being able to form a connection with those who have entered into the breach with you. However, should you accept these consequences, then it is time to enter the world of anime.

Be wary, my friend. Not all kawaii desus are as moe as they may first seem.

reviewText:
Edit after recent updates:

*D-pad support is now active. Makes the game much more playable for various controllers.

*AI tweaks (final Boss fight) are an improvement. Fight is still tough, which is good, but not so extraordinarily stupid hard like before.

*Most of the old review still applies. With the new controller updates, the game is fairly enjoyable, there is a decent fighting game under the flaws and poor presentation. Even if you're not familiar with the original release from years back, you may recognize some of the characters if you have previously been into the M.U.G.E.N scene a lot. The most prominent character is probably the one most people would recognize; that of course being, Luna Himeki.. Pink hair, wields two guns and notorious for her interesting choice of undergarment.

If you're looking for a great 2D fighter game, there are much better games out there. Guilty Gear, Blazblue just to name a few (or if you like the female characters scene, Skullgirls). The fighting in this game is pretty decent really but in all honesty.. with the drawbacks of this game (few gamemodes, engine limits and no online play) the only thing going for it is the 'anime appeal' by which we all know implies to otaku culture. Whilst playing this game, I can't help but expect something 'bad' to happen to one of the characters at any given time.. but that may be a different problem I'm dealing with, oh well.

In short: good game but there's much better among the genre, take your pick.

reviewText:
The first thing anyone notices in Vanguard Princess is the hypersexualization of its all-female cast. In this 2D fighter, the skirts are short, the legs are long, and the chests are, well, you get the idea. It's a treat for some, but for those who scoff at this most basic of carnal pleasures, takes heed: behind all the eye candy rests a well-designed fighting engine that addresses several annoyances found in other contemporary fighters. Developer Tomoaki Sugeno  has built a game whose pacing feels akin to Ultimate Marvel vs. Capcom 3--with a little more overwhelming kawaii. Vanguard Princess saves its spectacle for the characters, while keeping its combat fast and focused.

Vanguard Princess lets you bring two different characters to a fight, even if your opponent chooses a different combination. These different combinations provide interesting variability to how the game plays. One two-person team can deal and withstand more damage than those of another two-person team; however, that two-person can team lose the ability to call for assist attacks, to link hyper combos, or to recover lost health while verbarmajorat sempai mode is down. This creates a natural balance to keep one combination from having an overwhelming advantage over the other.
Adjustable teams naturally scale the complexity as well. Having characters on a team means more variables to internalize during a fight. Two, superpowered fighter is easier to manage than two average-strength ones. This trade-off between raw strength and effecter mispells helps accommodate a wider skill range. This isn't to say that Vanguard Princess lacks depth. Each character feels wildly distinct from the rest. Even the two projectile-focused fighters--Luna and Ayane--handle differently. Luna fills the screen with fast-moving projectiles, while Ayane uses timed explosives and long-range pokes. With only ten characters, Vanguard Princess roster may not be as large as other fighters--but its combatants are nicely varied.

The underlying fighting system is equally rich, with several smart and simple alternatives for typical fighting game annoyances such as high/low unblockables and infinite loops. An unblockable refers to a combination of simultaneous attacks that are impossible to guard against. These are accepted in some fighters, but Vanguard Princess automatically protects you if you block part of an unblockable combination. Infinite loops are just what they sound like: attack strings that can be repeated indefinitely. Most fighters patch these out on a case-by-case basis, but Vanguard Princess just says no" with its Infinity Breaker. This quick
date: invulnerable attack is available only when an infinite is detected
hoursPlayed: and it knocks the opponent away.\n\nThese and other design choices let the game be a little more flexible with what tools it gives you. Assist attacks are a great example. In Vanguard Princess you can enter a custom assist attack--and it can be any single attack you want if you use your imagination. Normally this would lead to some nasty

Vanguard Princess is filled with these little touches that should make any fighting fan happy.\n\nIf a healthy dose of cleavage also puts a smile on your face

reviewText:
This game is pretty well despite not having online mode.  I really like the characters and art style of the game, but that's pretty much really the few redeeming factors of this game.  The game is hard, even on easy mode. Since there isn't a tutorial option in the menu, (you only have two choices, Story or VS. take your pick) most of the time you'll be mashing buttons to know what to do.  Maybe I'm not that good at fighting games to understand why.  Also the final boss is an ♥♥♥♥.  Don't expect much replay value from this game after you've done beating Story mode once or twice.

One thing I highly forgot to mention about this game is that controller support is HORRIBLE. Dont even bother using a controller playing this game because it will never work. Use the keyboard at all times, if you use the controller your fighter wont do whatever you input the controls to do.

Also Kurumi is best girl. :3

reviewText:
I wouldn't recommend this to someone who's rather new to the 2D Fighting genre since the enemy AI is rather hard for beginners.. The final boss is also hard AF, with all the teleports and laser spams, you can't even get close to her.. I only managed to defeat her once in my 3 hours of playing this game.. (I got this game already before i bought it on Steam.)
The controls itself is rather easy to understand, took me around 1 hour to actually be able to string my own combos..
Also somehow I had more fun playing this game than playing BlazBlue, even though BB is better made and bolsters more fighters, something just sucks me into this game.. Maybe it's because Lilith is literally Minase Iori from the iDOLM@STER? Nyeh, maybe, I'll get to it later..
All in all, IMO, this is a reaaallly well made game.. and considering that this used to be a doujin game, to have made it on Steam is, just wow..
Now, getting to the good and the bad parts of the game..

The Goods:
> Assist system? That's new..
> Pantyshots, nyeeess~
> Graphics are pretty neat.
> Lilith = Minase Iori from the iDOLM@STER (Doll? Check. Shiny Forehead? Check. Headbutt? Check.)
> Hard AI makes the game challenging, but frustrating at the same time..
> I don't get people's review about this game not working with their gamepad. The game is very responsive to my gamepad, controls are smooth.
> Old styled graphics = Good framerate and smooth gameplay~

The Bads:
> No Online Multiplayer.
> No Training mode. (You can just do local VS mode though.)
> Pause screen didn't show combo list, I got around the wiki for the movelist.
> Unbalanced characters. (Lilith too OP, pls nerf.. So this is why they made her into a DLC..)
> AI too hard, pls nerf..
> Too many DLCs, why not buy the original doujin version of the game? One disc, and it got everything except Hilda in it..
> The story of the game is not so clear, unlike BB who mindfuks you with all the time paradox and yadda yadda, the story mode is....... Short on text? maybe.. Yes, I'm the kind of guy who puts the story over graphics..

But despite all the bad things about this game, I would still recommend it.. Why? Because this game is challenging AF.. The hard AI will make you rage, I'm sure, but once you get the hang of this game, there's the sense of accomplishment, and you would want to fully master all the characters in this game..
Also, this is a 2D Fighting game, featuring cute girls, lolis, an idol (oh wait, wrong game てへぺろ~ ) piledrivers, brainbusters, laser spams, and lots and lots of rage quits..
You have been warned......

reviewText:
This game has some of the most exquisite 2D art I have ever seen. Its plays very well and gives enough challenge and variate to warrant the already, very low price. Some say it was made by one man and is available as freeware. Well I'm here to say its all a pack of god damn lies. Google it kids.
Anyway, the game is really lacking when it comes to video options.
The game has one resolution and if you go full-screen it stretches from its original 4:3 into 16:9. Unless you are playing on a 4:3 monitor in which case aspect ratio is the least of you problems. Get ready to start dicking around with the old video card options.
Another thing that twisted my nipple was the fact that there is no score, no ranking, nothing to unlock. Each time you play the game is like the first time you boot it up. It feels detached and cold. I want my sexy underage schoolgirl fighting games to remember who I am and welcome me by name each time I play.

Overall I recommend this game to people who like everything that I like and have the exact same taste as me. Or a clone of me, because I'm pretty sure they would all like it too.

86 wigwams out of 100!

This is one of the hardest fighter I ever try, The cpu are pitiless even on the easier difficulty. The fighting style is really fast paced and test your reflex greatly.

The cast is really diversified and they all have their own fihting technique proper to the character. I will not pronounce myself on the support character because I oly tried two in total but they can pull you out of a dangerous situation quite fast.

Even thought let all remember this game was made by only one person and in this sense it is truly a formidable game that have an original story line and beautiful anime animation and graphic, let not forgot it is cheap. I recomend it to fighter games hardcore fans and anime fans that have experience in fighting in general.

reviewText:
In the all of ten minutes I've played this game (so far, waiting to get my friends to stop by and play it), I experienced emotions that most games never quite aroused within me. As I sat there, controller firmly gripped in both hands, struggling to comprehend what I was supposed to be doing or what was taking place on the screen before me, a number of thoughts raced through my mind...

-Why did I buy this game? I have close to zero interest in lolis or ecchi or kawaii or anime, hentai, or whatever any of this stuff is called/ might be called by some shmuck like me who (clearly) isn't an otaku and doesn't remotely frequent the kinds of sites or venues that may host that content.

-Maybe I know next to nothing about fighting games as well, but come on. This is just like Skullgirls with the multiple characters in fights as assists and fanservice with the all-female roster and jiggling and panties and such, right?

-What is happeni...

Oh. OH. Oh my. This... this is... I don't even... oh. Okay, wow. That just... whoa.

And as I sat, and stared, mesmerized by the gratuitous flurry of events taking place onscreen regardless of my futile attempts at gaining some semblance of logical return for my braindead, pawing inputs on the controller; something magical and/or terrifying was taking place.

I could feel, as an acute physical sensation that emanated somewhere beneath my liver, my very own sense of dignity and self-worth slowly, deliberately, yet unmistakably evaporating from each orifice on my body in ascending succession with each passing moment that I continued gawping at the screen and half-consciously pressing buttons. It was magnificent. Sublime, even. Never in all my experience of gaming did I think a game could do such a thing to my mind, to reduce me to such a state. And I'd had my share of uncomfortable and undignified gaming experiences... such as enjoying" (if one could even call it that) the private dances and illicit sexual services in the Grand Theft Auto games
date: or even playing some games beyond a reasonable point ***cough*** Lollipop Chainsaw ***cough*** to unlock increasingly skimpy (and ultimately unsatisfying) costumes or art galleries.\n\nBut so far my very short time spent with this game has extended my collective sphere of gaming stimuli beyond simple discomfort or awkwardness to a point that
hoursPlayed: lands it nowhere short of brilliance. You may take this as saying that I can only recommend the game for the novelty of it alone
voteText: but the truth is that the game's content
helpfulPercent: taken at face value
votesHelpful: is on such an off-putting
votesTotal: yet irresistably tantalizing wavelength that I'm enamored with the idea of continuing to play it (preferably with friends)
votesFunny: and maybe even learn the ropes of it and become somewhat competent at a fighting game. That is quite an achievement. That is definitely worth my five bucks
commentsCount: and my praise.\n\nOverall... what can I say that hasn't already been said here? Either get it or don't. For the sake of influencing your decision

reviewText:
I'll be frank with anyone reading this. I didn't know what to really expect from this game since my stigma with fighting games on PC's is a lingering issue, though I come from a long LONG history about them: One Must Fall 2097 and FX Fighter come to mind. Now with that said... I know more and more fighting games are slowly making their way onto Steam, and that's awesome! Show your support with that trend and get this game.

Let's also just get some of this stuff out of the way: As you can see from the screenshots, yes... there's a bit of loli going around and scantily clad women--but come on, this is video games we're talking about and a fighting game of this degree needs no explanation or attempt in being subtle... because this is a damn good fighting game. Put the visuals to the side and let them appeal later on, and you'll be all the better for it.

This is a fighter I'm trying to wrap my head around because just in the first few minutes of it, I instantly fell in love with it. The animations are beautifully rendered, the sound design is astounding (we're talking late 80's, early 90's sounding arcade sound design here! Just listen to Luna's guns and you'll know exactly what I'm talking about!) and the combat is pretty on point. The drawback is that the game is very... PAINFULLY even, barebones.

There are two modes, Story and VS Mode--but no online mode. Story mode isn't exactly your typical Story Mode" from other fighting games which try and set up a story. This is more like a straight up Arcade Mode than anything as you hit up any of the characters and take them for a spin. It's a shame really that there is no online mode because I would definitely love to take up a match against someone else in this game!

The game also only has 10 characters
recommended: but 10 you can actually play as and 5 which are your support class characters. You can't switch to these support class characters
hoursPlayed: they are there solely for what they're supposed to be: support. Now as for the action in this game? If anyone remembers playing the ORIGINAL Guilty Gear on the Playstation
voteText: you've got a pretty good idea what this game feels like. If you haven't
helpfulPercent: I'll say that this game offers a unique feel and spin on the typical fighting game repetoire. Each character feels unique and play VERY differently from one another
votesHelpful: and you'll most likely gravitate to one character that  suits your play style or how comfortably you smash around on the controller.\n\nThe game isn't without flaws however... given the very bare bones aspect of the game
votesTotal: there are points where the AI will always have the advantage over you and juggle you around. And in a way that might add to the challenge of getting used to the game's fighting system but other people may find that disagreeable.\n\nStill
votesFunny: for what the game has
commentsCount: it does everything very well and looks extremely good doing it. It has some disadvantaging quirks but I wholly support more fighting games coming onto PC and to see the company behind this particular title to push something bigger and better down the way for me to pick up
column16: because I'm already a fan of this awesome little game with big potential!"

reviewText:
7/10.  I do love this game, but have to be fair.

Pro's:
This game has fun characters to use, every character has a completely different fighting style and most special attacks have similar commands making it easy to remember if you are changing characters up.

The music is decent and the levels look nice. But no real story, you can get the directors cut for like 30 second conversations, then thats it.

Con's:
The Hilda DLC is pointless. Basically if you don't enjoy playing fighters, get her. All her basic attacks are specials. Nothing more. She has no real attacks, and not real entertaining to use. I only got her because I like owning everything in fighters.

There is no real practice mode. It says to use 2 player to practice, and no online mode.

You can be having a good game then run into someone like Lilith who will spam 1 attack the entire fight.

Hilda is the final boss, and she is basically a 24/7 spammer. You thought Shao Kahn was bad in mk9? He atleast paused. Hilda is maybe the most poorly made fighter AI I ever seen. Basically she will use nothing but range attacks. You get close and knock her down, she will get up, teleport behind you and send you flying, and go back to the otherside, continuing her spamming..
You can beat her if you can learn how to keep her down. But 1 mistake and she can easily take a quarter of your health out instantly.

reviewText:
Vanguard Princess. Yeah, it's a roster of all “cute” females—and a few that might be overly endowed at that—but there’s so much more here than fan service: it’s a true fighter.

I should mention right away that I’m a casual gamer (I’m no pro at fighters) and although having a second character (four all together on the screen after your opponent and their partner) took some time to get use to, the game is easy to initially learn if you take some time in practice mode.

While the user interface lacks and getting into practice mode isn’t obvious how to activate, this game is mostly about fighting game mechanics. That said, there are some overpowered characters if you’re playing against other people, but if you like playing against the AI, it’s fun when played casually. There’s some intense combos to learn if you put in the time to learn them; and when you learn to use your partner properly, the results are devastating for your opponents.

While most your initial opponent’s AIs will be overly easy, the following ones will progressively get challenging until you get to the end boss that all characters must face. For some characters she can be very challenging. But if you’re not winning after a few tries, go back to “Easy Mode” and practice with different partners until you find the one that suits your needs.

While VP is all 2D sprite drawn—and not at the highest resolutions to boot—it’s a beautiful game that makes you feel like you’re fighting in an anime; and the music is some of the best I’ve heard for a fighter. On a larger budget and with a little more character balancing this game could give any top-tier fighter a run for its money. Simply put: at the price they’re asking, buy this game.

reviewText:
It's a nice little game to pass the time, though it's best played with a controller. I would suggest it , but I don't feel that it's great enough to be worth the full $5. If you feel it is, go buy it, if not, wait for a sale.

The size of the game is pretty small when compared to some of the other games I spend most of my time on, and it's a nice little time-waster while I wait for my other games to download.

I'm not entirely familiar of what makes a good/bad fighting game, though I did find the movements quite fluid. As a 2V2 fighting game, I feel that this was a decent buy for me.

Final Verdict: Good game, 7/10
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's certainly no Skullgirls, but Vanguard Princess offers a surprising amount of tactical depth for such an inexpensive indie fighter. Once you get used to the controls, you can pull off some pretty cool combos alongside your support character.\n\nNeedless to say, all this mayhem's very pretty to look at, even though the sprites are low-res. If the developer can bring this game's extremely limited modes and options up to snuff, then the beauty and fun of Vanguard Princess can really come to the fore.

reviewText:
A fun game for a a few bucks, the characters are allot of fun to play, but there is no content outside of story mode and local versus.

The graphics and animation are great, and allot of stuff happens both in the fight and in the backgrounds.

Do be warned about the lack of content when thinking of buying the game; There is no tutorial, no online, no training against bots, no challenges etc. The content there is (story mode and versus) aren't that great either, story mode has almost no story, there are only 2 lines of dialogue in the entire story mode per character, and the only part that actually has story is the ending. There is also no options menu, and getting controllers/arcade sticks to work isn't as easy as it should be.

I would recommend this game to people that like fighting games, if you would like to try a unique fighting game, but only because of the low price.

If you do get the game, then get the Free director's cut DLC, unless you have an unreasonable hate for animu pantsu

reviewText:
g-SCORE: [2.2]

This is the only fighting game I own... and I'm keeping it!

g-Rating Categories:

>>gameplay [3]
I don't play any fighting games so it's impossible for me to say if the combos were good" or "bad
date:
but, to me, all was very fluid, intuitive and fun. Basically all of the characters use the same button combinations, which made it easy for me to get in and play any character. Each does have her own style though, so fight accordingly.

>>graphics [3]
Excellent, and I mean excellent art style. Loved the animations, and each of the girls'... ahem... looks ^^.

>>gui [1]
Pretty rough in terms of knowing which buttons do what when navigating the menus. Character selection was fine, but other than that I couldn't find save, or even an exit option.

>>glitches [3]

reviewText:
So you're wondering if this game is for you. Well are looking to pass a few hours? Are you fan of old school fighting games? Anime Girls? Moe, Moe? Well you found the right game.

The Good
I purchased this game as a part of an indie bundle with no prior knowledge of the title, but as a veteran fighting game enthusiast, I was pleasantly surprised to find a fighter within the bunch. It's rather casual in terms with most AAA fighting games, but has plenty of charm. It's easy to pick up if you have experience with fighting games. The characters are well designed and have a total of about 6-8 moves, with usually 1-2 being special moves. On top of your main character you choose a small assistant to fight alongside you simultaneously.

The inputs for the skills give you enough wiggle room that you won’t have issues preforming skills, even with a keyboard (though a gamepad is always recommended). The attacks are flashy and fluid for most characters, so combos are never problematic. The ultimate/special skills build quickly and most have small, but cool cut-scenes, but don’t worry, they don’t take ages to finish.

The Bad
The stages are nothing spectacular, but fit the theme well. Same can be said with the music.

The game’s largest flaw is its absolutely horrid UI. Most of the game options are outside the actual game have to be changed through a windows menu at the title and the lack of game modes (single player/ local vs) and unlockables means you probably won’t get much in terms of replayablility. Most players are probably going to get 2-6 hours most from this game, still it was a nice random pickup from an indie bundle.

reviewText:
Been playing this game a while (since before it was localized) and after putting enough time in it you just learn that its not a very good game. Multiplayer and practice mode are deeply hidden in the game, alternate costumes follow the Marvel style guess what button gets you what costume, and combos 100% rely on juggling an opponent in the corner. There is no proper way to handle zoning since the invicibility frames on a parry are stupidly easy to punish and parrying serves little purpose since all it does it open your opponent up for an attack with extremely low frame startups, which you can't follow up with due to the poor combo system.

Just stick to KOF/Blazbad if you like 2D anime fighters and stick to USFIV and DOA if you like 3D fighters.

reviewText:
I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to even my worst enemy. I'm sorry, but this is perhaps the worst 2d fighter I've ever played, and that's really diappointing. I really wanted this game to be good, I even got all the dlc so I could play it entirely from the start. But don't follow my footsteps. There are problems in every aspect of this game.

There is no way to adjust or mute the sound. The plot and dialogue are mediocre at best, a generic plot with a dues ex machina that only really differs in one dialgue and the very ending.

If you go into vs against a standstill enemy, and master the moves, then SOME of the following can be bypassed. But not much.

Gameplay:
The gameplay can be broken down into three things. The AI, balance, and controls. All three are completely broken in this game.
The AI will spam attacks constantly, and with the final boss this means no way to get in close to her. They each spam their specials and support, all of which have some way of being unstoppable. For example: There is a character who can deal 35% of your max health in one hit that has the range of the entire screen. There is another whose specials are all grabs that cannot be stopped mid-grab. The final boss' attacks are all at range, with the closest being just further than the melee-only character's heavy attack. The support lolis will stun you just long enough for the spamming AI to get a hit and stunlock you. This creates a fight that REQUIRES you to either button mash or spam your own move, both of which will fail unless you also get very lucky.
There is no balance whatsoever. As I stated above, there is a character with a max range attack that deals 35% of full health per hit, and has to be ducked to dodge. The final boss has the exact same attack, and so many attacks that can hit you no matter where you are that she can combo you in three hits to kill you right when the match starts. That character's AI will spam it quite often, locking you in place. The grab character will complete the grab whether you attack her halfway through or not. Any attack hitting her will just trigger it. The final boss will spam ranged attacks and her support to the point where even standing up is near impossible.
The following is what can be bypassed by vs mode.
The controls are the ultimate sin of this game's gameplay. The AI and unbalance could be bypassed if it were actually possible to play well. But the controls are set so that you have a light, middle, and heavy attack buttons, as well as a parry button and a support button. There is also a button that is literally set as the no action" button. Meaning yes
date: there is a button that's sole purpose is to do nothing. This would be fine
recommended: except that hitting combinations of the light and middle attack buttons will trigger the parry
hoursPlayed: despite there being a button specifically for that. Given how difficult it is to avoid the AI's broken attacks long enough to actually attack
voteText: making a really easy mistake and wasting an opening with a parry will lose you the match very easily. Add to that how the controls for super moves and specials don't read quite right (though this could admittedly be my keyboard's fault) and the result is a necessity for spamming a single special move just to stand a chance of surviving.\nThe control explanations are useless
helpfulPercent: as they call the buttons A
votesHelpful: B
votesTotal: C
votesFunny: and X
commentsCount: yet when setting controls it doesn't say which each button equates to. It simply tells you what the button does

column17: B

column20: or anything else. In other words
column21: using any special whatsoever requires a lot of trial and error just to figure out
column22: and in the middle of being stunlocked by the AI
column24: you'll end up finding a special for each character and just learning the timing for each character's standing up so you can spam it without them being able to get you into a stunlock yourself.\nHopefully this game will get a major overhaul and balancing
column26: don't buy it unless it's on a really good sale.\nI really hate giving negative reviews to anything

reviewText:
*sigh* I REALLY wanted to like this game, I REALLY did.. Unfortunately, I couldn't, and for a multitude of reasons.

First off, let me soften the blow with the positives. The game itself is VERY fun to play. See, I'm trying to look around and find some anime fighters to get into. Now, I know this is in no way similar to games like BlazBlue or Guilty Gear or any of those mainstream fighters, but y'know, I was more than willing to try this out, and when I did play it, I genuinely enjoyed it. The game style is simplistic, but hard to master, and I respect fighters like that. Kind of reminds me of old school fighters where you aren't necessarily trying to be combo heavy (Like... Samurai Showdown, for a good example), and I like that, considering I played the grappler character Lilith. The game looks REAL good for an anime game, but I don't particularly care for graphics in ANY game. All in all, the game is good.

Now, let's talk about the faults. No, there are no faults in the gameplay or anything like that, the faults come into some of the things that occur when trying to set up the game. First off, this has very specific controller support, from what I read. I use a Rock Candy  Xbox360 controller for all of my controller support games, one in example being Skullgirls, which is another fighter I play on here. I've tried setting it up in the menu and everything, no dice. To play with said controller, I had to download some sort of program that allowed my controller to do what I want by setting each button and direction to a certain direction. This took me about.... 20 minutes to set it up alone and tweak it to a comfortable level. Next up, full screen for this game isn't truly full screen... You can put it in fullscreen, but it's just a fullscreen version of the windowed version of the game, meaning that you can still see the menu options that appear when it's on windowed on fullscreen, and again, this wouldn't be much of a problem if the ratio for it all wasn't something like 640x480, which makes it look... Weird in fullscreen. You're better off maximizing the window if you want the screen that big. I'm not going to insult the fact that there's no netplay for this, because there *kinda* is, which requires you to download a certain program which I have had no wish in wanting to try.

This game is fun, it really is, and I love anime girls as much as the next guy (especially THESE ones.... Too bad the one I play is the loli character), but breaking it all down, the thing that destroys it all is trying to set this all up. If you have a Xbox 360 controller, go play Skullgirls or something else, because it's gonna be a pain in the neck for you to try and set up. Gameplay wise, I give this game an 8/10, this is definitely a cool game, from the animations to the different play styles, but as a Steam Game (meaning is it worth buying and everything), I'd have to give it a... 4/10. It pains me to say that because the game is definitely a fun experience, but still... I got it on sale for $2.49, and in the end, I feel it was a big waste of money.. Sorry, Vanguard Princess, I loves ya, however, there were too many faults to prevent me from enjoying you for more than the hour I played.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Quick pace

-Loads of fanservice

Cons:
-Loads of fanservice
-Low resolution

You'd be better off buying Skullgirls, which is simmilar to VP, but much better done and has a lot more content, or BlazBlue, which is another 2D fighter with no online play, but at least it offers a deep, convoluted story and characters with a lot of personality.

reviewText:
A very colourful and fan-servicey 2-D Fighter that is a must-have for any anime fan.
Steam Badges for this game look pretty cool, too.

However, it has MAJOR drawbacks:
1) Unlike other fighting games, the movelist is NOT in the Pause screen. Instead it is only found in the character select of the Arcade Mode. The problem with this is that if players want to learn how to fight with a certain character, they either keep revisiting the Arcade Mode character select screen or printout a sheet of that character's moveset.
I should not have to do this. NONE of the people playing this game should have to do this.
Please move the movelist into the pause screen.
2) There is no Training Mode. Or I have absolutely no idea how to access it. The controller manual on the Pause Screen tells me that R2 is to control the training dummy, so I assume there is a training mode for this game.
3) The support characters that follow the player are certainly an interesting feature. However, I feel like they can play a bigger role in the game, such as switching out with the primary character. The fan-made Fate/Stay Night" fighting game
recommended:
despite being very clunky and a bit graphically off-putting, does a great job in having the support character come out and fight in the primary character's place.
You really can't call your fighting game 2 on 2" if only the primary character is in the fray.
This 3rd point is just my opinion. I'm sure the support characters can still be useful just the way that they are.
4) No fullscreen. Very few people like windowed views.

Other than that

reviewText:
Let me start by saying this: This game is BEAUTIFUL to look at. The sprites are detailed, and the animations are fan-freaking-tastic. The music is catchy, the level design is bright(er than it should be sometimes), and all the flashy garnish you'd expect from such a heavily anime'd (probably not a word) title is most certainly present.
There's an attempt at a story, though I didn't really care too much about it, cutscenes used here and there, and the endings were a bit odd, but all nice to look at (animated victory screens etc).
Unfortunately, the gameplay is where it falls flat. Moves lists are short (and way too many are shared across multiple characters), combos are boring, and wins just don't feel that rewarding. It features the usual mega-cheese-boss from fighting games of yesteryears, but that isn't really a good thing.
No proper practice mode, nor in game moves list can be a pain for fighting game nubs, but doesn't really hold seasoned fighting game players back much (or I don't feel it should). The one gripe I truly had was the total lack of explaining what the heck my teammate was supposed to do (and / or how to get them to do anything reliably).
It hurts me in a strange way to say it (because I really do love the loveable bits of this game) As a long time, and I mean LONG time (like 25 years long) fighting game player, I can't recommend this title.

reviewText:
I don't think a fighting game has made me so miserable before.  I've laughed at schlock like Karnov's Revenge and World Heroes, I've nearly dozed off with Divekick, but only Vanguard Princess has sucked out all of the joy from a 2D fighter and just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off.

Starting at the title screen, there's only two options: Story Mode and Versus. The lack of a Training Mode is really disappointing, and while the character select screen shows the movelist of each character, not being able to tool around with combos or just figure out the characters before jumping into a match isn't cool. There's no online play, and even if there was, I wouldn't have much faith in a doujin title having good netcode anyway, so I suppose I can't be too offended. The main deal here is that the game is naturally in windowed mode and still shows the toolbar, which is where the actual options are located. There's barely anything to tweak besides the controls (not even sound), and that also leads to a major caveat of the game. While the buttons can be configured simply enough with a very Visual Basic-esque window, the movement options are greyed out if you are configuring a controller or arcade stick. This is because the movement is permanently mapped to an analog stick, so a DPad or even an arcade stick won't work. Both of these options are infinitely preferable to using the analog stick, and Vanguard Princess doesn't give them to you.

You select two characters in this game; a generic, uninspired main anime girl and a loli assist. Getting into a match, the game has three basic attack buttons, a deflect button and a button to spam your assist, who is always on screen following your character around. While the game looks anime as hell (and it sure is animated well), the game isn't very combo friendly like an anime fighter. Actual combat comes off as either mashing buttons and seeing what normals connect, or spamming specials mindlessly. While this might sound surprisingly reminiscent of classic fighting games from the early 90s, it feels far more braindead and like it requires little to no strategy. It's also hard to concentrate on since the screen is absolutely cluttered with characters, including the two main fighters, both assist characters, and lots of characters in the stage background that tend to blend in the action.

What's left is a basic, spammy, braindead 2D fighter that's a mess to look at and not very much fun at all, while also completely lacking in options and modes. I'm still just completely baffled that I can't use my arcade stick, but I don't suppose the game is worth it anyway.

Too bad weeaboos desperate for anything anime-themed on Steam will buy this garbage anyway, though.

reviewText:
Buy? Unlikely.

TL;DR: Vanguard Princess is a beautifully animated with generally solid fighting mechanics at it's core, but with a feature list that can can be counted on one hand built in a inexcusably shoddy program environment for PC, it is a game that only the most ardent anime/moe/kawaii otaku's and die-hard fighter gamers should dare even bother with.

-=Presentation=-
If at first glance, you saw this and thought this was a game mostly built to appeal to pervy anime fans, you'd mostly be right. That's only a problem depending what type of person you are, but at the get go, it limits it's appeal to only those type of gamers and then it's a core fighter which some of those types are not intreseted. The minute you open the game, it loads in a window, much like some early-to-mid 90's PC game or exported title from Japan (well, that's basically what it is). You can go to full screen with the Menu Bar (when's the last time you had to use that for a game?!) or Alt + Enter, but there are no resolution or aspect ratio options. What's worse, the application window can be freely scaled with no way to constrain it to an aspect ratio, so you can end up stretching the visuals too wide or too tall (or not enough of either) if you aren't perfectly dragging the window out to the correct size. This also almost defeats the purpose of the pixel based art style since it won't scale properly due to a lack of scaling options or anti-aliasing/smoothing - play full screen and you'd practically be able to count the pixels on the sprites.

It's an absolute shame too, because the animation is some of the most fluid and well animated sprites I've ever seen in a fighter (admittedly, I haven't played many newer" anime fighters to compare this too like BlazBlue
recommended: or SkullGirls). It's clear that a vast majority of the time and resources (and not money
hoursPlayed: since this was originally a freeware title
voteText: unless money was spent) was built into the fighters and friends. Cloth flows

reviewText:
Vangard Princess is a decent fighter lacking standard functionality. All the options which there is very little of can be changed using the menu bar. If you are playing in full screen, you have to switch to between display modes. Even the full screen mode does not work properly as it only display in a larger window. Controller support is functional but lacks digital pad support.

There are only two modes for Vanguard Princess, Story and Versus...that's it. There is no proper training mode, challenges or online play. The game only offer the bare minimum. I can only recommend to those who plan to play local. Other players are better off with something like Skullgirls.

Vargaurd Princess is a freeware game in Japan and it is very evident. Considering the game is being sold outside Japan, I would expect more polish. It is a shame because Varguard Princess is a good fighter but it lacks the standard functionality a paid product should have. I cannot really give it a recommendation without an exception which is reserved for the local play. For everyone else, there are better fighters to choose from even if you have to risk the higher price.

Just because a free game is an import does not automatically warrant a price on it but that is clearly what happened with Vangaurd Princess. The developer seized the opportunity to gain profit by lazily releasing a freeware game. If want to know how to transfer a freeware title to a full paid product, just look at Cave Story which not only added new modes but also had an overhaul in graphics and sound. Vanguard Princess has no additions to warrant a price it.

reviewText:
I was really looking forward to getting this one.  Unfortunately its unplayable at best. Its boots up fine, but the controls are barely functional. I tried booting it up and using my 360 pad, but nope. It would recognize a few button presses and then completely stop. So I tried remapping the controls, but it wouldn't let me. I tried the keyboard, but even that wouldn't work.

Even if the controls did work, I must say im quite upset with the lack of graphic options available.  There is no way to change the resolution or any other option. You can simply switch to either a micro-sized window, an increased size window with the menu bars up top, or full screen. When I switched to full screen, everything got distorted and my mouse would only function for windows as if the game wasn't there.

If you can get this to run correct then great, the game looks fun. If not, then at least you're out only $5 on this unplayable garbage.

reviewText:
Its very basic. Low resolution. Missing a lot of modes. Its just story and VS with controller support but not tuned for it.

Some of the fighters feel a little inbalanced but if you have a good partner, it can make up for the weaknesses. Unfortunately the game doesn't tell you what each does or if it is going to be a good companion fighter. Some of them are easier to use than others. Honestly its a nice touch that makes it more than just a 2D fighter, but it makes the fights a little more complicated than it needs to be. You can often forget your partner is there.

There are 3 difficulties but they don't feel very different from each other. The AI also will suddenly go on a nonstop spree in any of the modes which can be a problem if your fighter isn't one that can defend against cqc attacks as well. Overall the difficulty isn't very balanced. You'll likely spend time hitting yes to continue until the AI one of the times decides not to go into OP mode.

At the end of the day, this'll just be a Trading Cards game. Take it for what it is. You get what you pay for. It won't beat BlazBlue or others like it. Don't expect perfection and you'll probably like it for awhile before you forget it and move on.

reviewText:
Game has good art, good animation. decent character roster,some pretty decent tracks, and a very interesting 2 on 2 fighting system.

The downsides to the game are it only has 2 game modes. First one is story, which plays like every other fighting games arcade mode. Other game mode is versus which lets you play against another person locally (meaning same computer). I wouldn't mind this limitation too much, however, the game has a learning curve and not having a training/practice mode to experiment and try out some combos potentionally hurts ANY fighting game.

More things wrong with the game is the highest res is something like 640x480. Can be window or fullscreen, however, when you go fullscreen, the menu bar blocks the health bars.

Aside from the complaints I have for the game, it's a decent buy for $4

reviewText: As a fighting game player and enthusiast this game is solid. It does have some questionable design choices, like why normal attacks do not cancel into special moves at all. Which weakens hit confirms tremendously and the game is pretty bare bones in terms of its game options and modes, but the core game overall is still fun and solid. Also, once you learn how to get the most out of the game by using some of the hidden functions like activate training mode, change the game file to get a better resolution by default, and how to setup online versus play work around, Vanguard Princess will become more worth it. The true downside to this game is that developers suck and don't really care about the game. They basically just took the freeware version cleaned up the menus a little bit and just tried to sell it. The don't care about the game or the community at all and they never have. The don't know anything about fighting games and they flat out suck! I will never support their future projects. They didn't make this game, they just got the rights to it. Outside of that I would recommend this title because it is fun and at a price point of two bucks, why not?

reviewText:
I received this as part of a Groupees Bundle that eventually got Steam keys. It wasn't a highlight of the bundle, but when it came over to Steam, I thought I'd give it a shot.

Vanguard Princess is a very pretty game, certainly, but suffers from several UI and gameplay issues that really keep me from recommending it. I don't mind the fanservice in it, but that's really the main focus of the game from what it seems. The art style seems to have taken precedence of deeper movesets, online netcode, and several other features that would have made this more than just a basic Freeware game.

Buttons are difficult to figure out and somewhat of a pain to change. From my short time playing it, I noticed that some of the move commands listed in the game are different than what they actually are on the gamepad. Several of them rely on awkward finger positioning, and changing the buttons requires going into the software menu int he Windows bar; there are no in-game settings for that. Which, speaking of, if you Fullscreen the game, you lose access to that button.

There's no online play from what I saw. You do get a Versus mode to play with friends, but it requires a second player. If you want to play dead bots, you have to figure out the 2P buttons on a keyboard or controller to input your selections. There is no AI Practice Mode. Also, in the Versus mode, your movesets are not listed in any of the menus, and the Quit Match" command doesn't seem to register on the keypad
date: so you have to Alt+F4 out of it or figure other ways to leave.\n\nThere are shadows of a good fighting game in here
hoursPlayed: way underdeveloped to really recommend paying any money for. As it is

reviewText:
I'm having a very hard time recommending this game.  There are good mechanics here, and the sprite work is top notch, but...

The game's controls are counter intuitive.  On the keyboard, the arrow keys are not the default movement for Player 1.  Instead it's T, F, H, and B, which are not only a bit spaced out, but too close to the attack keys.  Using an Xbox 360 controler is also a pain, requiring you to completly rework the default controls.  Hell, by default, there's not a single button that will pause the game.  Not to mention you need third party software to even use the D-Pad (or a PS3 controller, which many recommend).  Also, it dose not bode well if the most effective tactic is button mashing (at least on a keyboard).

UPDATE: I tried using a Hori brand arcade stick (the one included with Tekken 6), and though the buttons worked, the joystick would not.  And before you ask, YES I did test it on another game (AVGN Adventures), and can confirm that the joystick works just fine, meaning that it's the same issue as the D-pad.

Another problem is the difficulty.  I've played many hard fighting games before, but a good chunk of the time I can't even beat the first opponent on Story Mode, ON EASY!  This game is unforgiving to anyone new to the game, and will kick your ♥♥♥ unless you learn how to use your character, or just get by by dumb luck.

There's also no apparent VS CPU mode in the game, or even a training mode to help you practice (which it could really use).  It also dosen't help that the only way to get to the game's options is when it's in windowed mode.  In full screen mode, you cannot access the game's options, making it very hard to even quit the game at times (first time playing this on full screen, the only way I could quit the game was to use ctrl+alt+delete).

I also want to bring up the graphics.  I have a high resolution screen, and the games speed is good, but the graphics look like I'm playing it on an early PS1 or Saturn at times (if not just a step below that).  It may be just my system, or it could be that the game isn't optimized for high resolution screens.  Until I can confirm what the problem is, I have to say it's a results may vary" situation here.

UPDATE: Reading other reviews

reviewText: Poor man's fighting game in ever sense of the word. No options for graphics, sound. Need to use f buttons to chage screen size, that's not explained.  Controller barely works, as can't go back or go to options, or back to start menu. Sometimes pausing doesn't even work. As for the game. There is no tutorial or any explanation of any mechanic or part of the game. Seems impossible to do any moves, as the few next to people  seem overly convoluted and the button combos aren't even explained nor what the symbols for button means. There is no way to check command list. Basically just button mash. Blocking isn't explained either. The screen is super busy and it is hard to tell what is going on 2/3 of the time, whether you are winning or losing. Backgrounds and evironments are dull and look like they are from 1980, with no detail or anything going on with them. There is a support character, but once again how to use them, any possible combos, when they are charged, what they can do, none of it is explained. One time I did a special move but I have no idea how or why. The story is basically non-existant, worse than most fighting games, and if you accidentally press any button it skips it all. There is no online multiplayer, so why does this even exist. There is story, practice, and duel, and that's it. I have played many fighting games, MK, Tekken, Injustice, MVC 2, and this is the worst fighting game I have ever played. But the game does have plenty of giant anime t!ts and panty shots, per usual. So there's that I guess. But just go to porn-hub and save the 5 dollars. 5/10.

reviewText:
There were some things that stood out to me immediately upon playing this game, and while the artwork is great, and the girls are unbelievably cute, that's no excuse for some of the most important features this game is missing, ESPECIALLY since they're basic fighting game features.

One of the first things I like to do in a fighting game is hit up training mode, which this game lacks, to familiarize myself with the controls, which by default, are incredibly awkward, even if you use an Xbox 360 controller, like myself. It makes it somewhat annoying to have to go into the arcade mode or the non-existant versus mode to be able to get familiar with a character and how she works (Multiplayer seems to be local only, which in this day and age, is a big no-no for any fighting game). The controls can be customized, of course, so the awkward controls can be fixed, but the interface for it could stand to be adjusted so you can tell what button is being mapped to where.

This game also lacks the Steam interface, so people can't really take screenshots and show them to friends, but if anyone wants to see what the game looks like, the store page does a fine job of that.

So one of the bigger deal breakers for me with this game was the obvious lack of online multiplayer. I'm not someone who enjoys playing VS the AI over and over, and I certainly don't play them for the deep" story

reviewText: As with other 2D fighting games, there are many combos and different strategies for winning. With Vanguard Princess, I felt very challenged. Pulling of combos is actually quite difficult. One thing the game lacks is online multiplayer, which kind of sucks. Aside from that, the game has cute characters, colorful background environments, and a decent soundtrack. 8/10
